comment.body:
As the error message indicates, the newly added token (piece) is already in the vocab. In addition, adding an empty piece is not allowed.

Manual updating of the model is out of the scope of support, so please update the model at your-own-risk-basis.

issue.title: Continuous Tokenizer Training
issue.body:
Hi there, 

Can we continue the training for a SentencePiece tokenizer? 
We got a English tokenizer with 10K vocab_size, and want to train the tokenizer on Chinese corpus to learn additional 5K tokens, to have a final tokenizer with 10K of English tokens at the beginning (start from index 0) and 5K of Chinese tokens follows (start from index 10,000). 
Can we do that?

comment.body:
Sentencepiece doesn't support continuous training, but you can try to merge two models (En/Zh models) trained independently.

The models file a serialized protobuf. We can merge the "pieces" fields in the proto.
https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/issues/121

pull_request.title: add CIFuzz GitHub action
pull_request.body:
Add [CIFuzz](https://google.github.io/oss-fuzz/getting-started/continuous-integration/) workflow action to have fuzzers build and run on each PR.

This is a service offered by OSS-Fuzz where sentencepiece already runs. CIFuzz can help detect regressions and catch fuzzing build issues early, and has a variety of features (see the URL above). In the current PR the fuzzers gets build on a pull request and will run for 300 seconds.

Signed-off-by: David Korczynski <david@adalogics.com>

I may be wrong, as far as I recalled, sentencepiece was released around June 6, 2022.

issue.title: Recommended corpus size
issue.body:
My corpus has 60+ millions sentences.

When I train a SentencePiece tokenizer I get the following warning : 

> LOG(WARNING) Too many sentences are loaded! (60775390), which may slow down training.

I thought having as many training data as possible was a good thing. **But is there a specific training data size "soft limit" (i.e. adding more data over this limit wouldn't really change the output) ?**

comment.body:
We do not always need to train the model from larger data. I think sampling is sufficient.
Ssuwbword algorithm only uses the frequent 32-64k tokens.  The trend of frequent tokens does not change that much after sampling.

issue.title: Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" and "？" are not contained in the vocab
issue.body:
I used about 35m Chinese corpus to generate the Chinese vocab, here is my command：
`spm_train --input=test.zh --model_prefix=spm_zh --vocab_size=32000 --character_coverage=1`
but the spm_zh.vocab doesn't contain Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" ,  "？", "；", "：". Instead, the spm_zh.vocab contains English half-width punctuation such as "," ,  "?", ";", ":". 
In fact, most of the lines in my training corpus use Chinese full-width punctuation but not English half-width punctuation. And Chinese full-width punctuation is different with English half-width punctuation. For example,
`ch = '，'  `
`en = ','  `
`print('ch punc', ch.encode('utf-8')) `
`print('en punc', en.encode('utf-8')) `
`>>ch punc b'\xef\xbc\x8c'`
`>>en punc b','`
I change other Chinese corpus and change vocab_size, however, the problem is still not solved.
Should I set other hyperparameters？

issue.title: Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" and "？" are not contained in the vocab
issue.body:
I used about 35m Chinese corpus to generate the Chinese vocab, here is my command：
`spm_train --input=test.zh --model_prefix=spm_zh --vocab_size=32000 --character_coverage=1`
but the spm_zh.vocab doesn't contain Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" ,  "？", "；", "：". Instead, the spm_zh.vocab contains English half-width punctuation such as "," ,  "?", ";", ":". 
In fact, most of the lines in my training corpus use Chinese full-width punctuation but not English half-width punctuation. And Chinese full-width punctuation is different with English half-width punctuation. For example,
`ch = '，'  `
`en = ','  `
`print('ch punc', ch.encode('utf-8')) `
`print('en punc', en.encode('utf-8')) `
`>>ch punc b'\xef\xbc\x8c'`
`>>en punc b','`
I change other Chinese corpus and change vocab_size, however, the problem is still not solved.
Should I set other hyperparameters？

comment.body:
sentencepiece normalizes the input with Unicode NFKC by default, which includes the full/half width punctuations.
You can suppress the normalization with ``--normalization_rule_name=identity``.  We can also define application dependent
normalization rules.

https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/blob/master/doc/normalization.md

comment.body: Let me close this bug as there is no update.

comment.body:
tf_sentencepiece is already deprecated and no longer supported. The released binary package does not include M2 binary, so this error is expected.

You might be able to build tf_sentencepiece from scratch. This issue might be useful.
https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/issues/367

issue.title: different between command line tool and python with \n
issue.body:
I used two different ways to train a spm,but I find that the result are different.
```python
spm.SentencePieceTrainer.Train(
                                input = '/mnt/tiny.txt',
                                model_prefix='unigram_tiny', 
                                vocab_size=50000, 
                                model_type='unigram', 
                                character_coverage=0.9995, 
                                num_threads=120,
                                train_extremely_large_corpus=True,
                                control_symbols=['[PAD]', '<s>', '</s>', '[SPEAKER1]', '[SPEAKER2]', '[SEP]'],
                                pad_id=0,
                                unk_id=1,
                                bos_id=2,
                                eos_id=3,
                                pad_piece='[PAD]',
                                unk_piece='[UNK]',
                                bos_piece='<s>',
                                eos_piece='</s>',
                                byte_fallback=True,
                                add_dummy_prefix=False,
                                remove_extra_whitespaces=False,
                                user_defined_symbols=['\n', '\t', '\r', '\b'],
                                logstream=open('train-unigram.log', 'w'))```
and command line with :
```bash
spm_train --input=/mnt/tiny.txt --model_prefix ch_unigram_tiny --vocab_size 50000 --character_coverage 0.9995 --model_type unigram --control_symbols [PAD],\<s\>,\</s\>,[SPEAKER1],[SPEAKER2],[SEP] --user_defined_symbols='\n','\t','\r','\b' --pad_id 0 --unk_id 1 --bos_id 2 --eos_id 3 --pad_piece [PAD] --unk_piece [UNK] --bos_piece \<s\> --eos_piece \</s\> --unk_surface [UNK] --byte_fallback --train_extremely_large_corpus true --add_dummy_prefix false --remove_extra_whitespaces false --num_threads 120
```
when use unigram_tiny model,it can tokenize '\n' as a piece of '\n', but use ch_unigram_tiny to tokenize '\n', it return '▁' .
after check the 'vocab', I find the different:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16846988/195792264-bab17080-5847-4d05-b05d-522be0d86aae.png)

it looks like command line tool keep a wrong user defined symbol.
so which is right?and if I want to keep '\n', the python way is a good way to go?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16846988/195792264-bab17080-5847-4d05-b05d-522be0d86aae.png)

comment.body: This is expected.  Unix shell usually handles the escape sequence as-is. i.e., the backslash is parsed as-is.

issue.title: create sentencepiece from own vocab file
issue.body:
I am very new to using sentencepiece.

I am trying to convert DNA sequences into sentencepiece. My file contains a list of sequences.
For example, two sequences would look like this:
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA
AAACGTGTGTGACCC
...
Using sentencepiece from pretrained English such as test/test_model.model, each DNA letter is considered a word. The ideal case would be to break down each sequence into a sequence of k-mers. For example,
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA consisting of three "words": ACTGC ACAGT CAGTA, if k=5. Is this possible?

It's not clear to me what model_file's are so I am not sure how to convert DNA sequences to sentencepiece. I am using the python module. Right now I am getting `RuntimeError: Internal: src/sentencepiece_processor.cc(891) [model_proto->ParseFromArray(serialized.data(), serialized.size())] `

My goal is to use BigBird in Huggingface, which uses sentencepiece tokenization.

I appreciate your help. Thanks.

comment.body:
We can limit the length of tokens with  ``--max_sentencepiece_length=5``. However, this setting extracts the pieces of length 1..5.

Creating the vocab is not supported. Currently, the model and vocab can only be generated with the trainer and the training data.
However, it is technically possible to manually edit the model file. Please check the previous threads.

As the error message indicates, the newly added token (piece) is already in the vocab. In addition, adding an empty piece is not allowed.

Manual updating of the model is out of the scope of support, so please update the model at your-own-risk-basis.

issue.title: Continuous Tokenizer Training
issue.body:
Hi there, 

Can we continue the training for a SentencePiece tokenizer? 
We got a English tokenizer with 10K vocab_size, and want to train the tokenizer on Chinese corpus to learn additional 5K tokens, to have a final tokenizer with 10K of English tokens at the beginning (start from index 0) and 5K of Chinese tokens follows (start from index 10,000). 
Can we do that?

comment.body:
Sentencepiece doesn't support continuous training, but you can try to merge two models (En/Zh models) trained independently.

The models file a serialized protobuf. We can merge the "pieces" fields in the proto.
https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/issues/121

Merge pull request #792 from DavidKorczynski/cifuzz-int

add CIFuzz GitHub action

pull_request.title: add CIFuzz GitHub action
pull_request.body:
Add [CIFuzz](https://google.github.io/oss-fuzz/getting-started/continuous-integration/) workflow action to have fuzzers build and run on each PR.

This is a service offered by OSS-Fuzz where sentencepiece already runs. CIFuzz can help detect regressions and catch fuzzing build issues early, and has a variety of features (see the URL above). In the current PR the fuzzers gets build on a pull request and will run for 300 seconds.

Signed-off-by: David Korczynski <david@adalogics.com>

issue.title: sentencepiece 0.1.97 re-released?
issue.body:
# Problem

I may be wrong, as far as I recalled, sentencepiece was released around June 6, 2022.

upstream monitoring system of debian, notified release of sentencepiece 0.1.97.
https://qa.debian.org/cgi-bin/watch?pkg=sentencepiece

Then that version of sentencepiece was packaged as 0.1.97-1.

After that, it seems that sentencepiece was released at Aug 7.
https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/releases/tag/v0.1.97

It causes mismatch of actual code base even though It says "0.1.97".
Could you release 0.1.98 in such a case?

Correct me, If I was wrong, @taku910

comment.body: We had several v0.1.97 releases, but only the last one is the official latest release, and others were labeled as "pre-release". (This release will be labeled as non-production ready).

issue.title: Recommended corpus size
issue.body:
My corpus has 60+ millions sentences.

When I train a SentencePiece tokenizer I get the following warning : 

> LOG(WARNING) Too many sentences are loaded! (60775390), which may slow down training.

I thought having as many training data as possible was a good thing. **But is there a specific training data size "soft limit" (i.e. adding more data over this limit wouldn't really change the output) ?**

comment.body:
We do not always need to train the model from larger data. I think sampling is sufficient.
Ssuwbword algorithm only uses the frequent 32-64k tokens.  The trend of frequent tokens does not change that much after sampling.

issue.title: Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" and "？" are not contained in the vocab
issue.body:
I used about 35m Chinese corpus to generate the Chinese vocab, here is my command：
`spm_train --input=test.zh --model_prefix=spm_zh --vocab_size=32000 --character_coverage=1`
but the spm_zh.vocab doesn't contain Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" ,  "？", "；", "：". Instead, the spm_zh.vocab contains English half-width punctuation such as "," ,  "?", ";", ":". 
In fact, most of the lines in my training corpus use Chinese full-width punctuation but not English half-width punctuation. And Chinese full-width punctuation is different with English half-width punctuation. For example,
`ch = '，'  `
`en = ','  `
`print('ch punc', ch.encode('utf-8')) `
`print('en punc', en.encode('utf-8')) `
`>>ch punc b'\xef\xbc\x8c'`
`>>en punc b','`
I change other Chinese corpus and change vocab_size, however, the problem is still not solved.
Should I set other hyperparameters？

issue.title: Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" and "？" are not contained in the vocab
issue.body:
I used about 35m Chinese corpus to generate the Chinese vocab, here is my command：
`spm_train --input=test.zh --model_prefix=spm_zh --vocab_size=32000 --character_coverage=1`
but the spm_zh.vocab doesn't contain Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" ,  "？", "；", "：". Instead, the spm_zh.vocab contains English half-width punctuation such as "," ,  "?", ";", ":". 
In fact, most of the lines in my training corpus use Chinese full-width punctuation but not English half-width punctuation. And Chinese full-width punctuation is different with English half-width punctuation. For example,
`ch = '，'  `
`en = ','  `
`print('ch punc', ch.encode('utf-8')) `
`print('en punc', en.encode('utf-8')) `
`>>ch punc b'\xef\xbc\x8c'`
`>>en punc b','`
I change other Chinese corpus and change vocab_size, however, the problem is still not solved.
Should I set other hyperparameters？

comment.body:
sentencepiece normalizes the input with Unicode NFKC by default, which includes the full/half width punctuations.
You can suppress the normalization with ``--normalization_rule_name=identity``.  We can also define application dependent
normalization rules.

https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/blob/master/doc/normalization.md

You might be able to build tf_sentencepiece from scratch. This issue might be useful.
https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/issues/367

issue.title: different between command line tool and python with \n
issue.body:
I used two different ways to train a spm,but I find that the result are different.
```python
spm.SentencePieceTrainer.Train(
                                input = '/mnt/tiny.txt',
                                model_prefix='unigram_tiny', 
                                vocab_size=50000, 
                                model_type='unigram', 
                                character_coverage=0.9995, 
                                num_threads=120,
                                train_extremely_large_corpus=True,
                                control_symbols=['[PAD]', '<s>', '</s>', '[SPEAKER1]', '[SPEAKER2]', '[SEP]'],
                                pad_id=0,
                                unk_id=1,
                                bos_id=2,
                                eos_id=3,
                                pad_piece='[PAD]',
                                unk_piece='[UNK]',
                                bos_piece='<s>',
                                eos_piece='</s>',
                                byte_fallback=True,
                                add_dummy_prefix=False,
                                remove_extra_whitespaces=False,
                                user_defined_symbols=['\n', '\t', '\r', '\b'],
                                logstream=open('train-unigram.log', 'w'))```
and command line with :
```bash
spm_train --input=/mnt/tiny.txt --model_prefix ch_unigram_tiny --vocab_size 50000 --character_coverage 0.9995 --model_type unigram --control_symbols [PAD],\<s\>,\</s\>,[SPEAKER1],[SPEAKER2],[SEP] --user_defined_symbols='\n','\t','\r','\b' --pad_id 0 --unk_id 1 --bos_id 2 --eos_id 3 --pad_piece [PAD] --unk_piece [UNK] --bos_piece \<s\> --eos_piece \</s\> --unk_surface [UNK] --byte_fallback --train_extremely_large_corpus true --add_dummy_prefix false --remove_extra_whitespaces false --num_threads 120
```
when use unigram_tiny model,it can tokenize '\n' as a piece of '\n', but use ch_unigram_tiny to tokenize '\n', it return '▁' .
after check the 'vocab', I find the different:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16846988/195792264-bab17080-5847-4d05-b05d-522be0d86aae.png)

it looks like command line tool keep a wrong user defined symbol.
so which is right?and if I want to keep '\n', the python way is a good way to go?

when use unigram_tiny model,it can tokenize '\n' as a piece of '\n', but use ch_unigram_tiny to tokenize '\n', it return '▁' .
after check the 'vocab', I find the different:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16846988/195792264-bab17080-5847-4d05-b05d-522be0d86aae.png)

it looks like command line tool keep a wrong user defined symbol.
so which is right?and if I want to keep '\n', the python way is a good way to go?

comment.body: This is expected.  Unix shell usually handles the escape sequence as-is. i.e., the backslash is parsed as-is.

issue.title: create sentencepiece from own vocab file
issue.body:
I am very new to using sentencepiece.

I am trying to convert DNA sequences into sentencepiece. My file contains a list of sequences.
For example, two sequences would look like this:
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA
AAACGTGTGTGACCC
...
Using sentencepiece from pretrained English such as test/test_model.model, each DNA letter is considered a word. The ideal case would be to break down each sequence into a sequence of k-mers. For example,
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA consisting of three "words": ACTGC ACAGT CAGTA, if k=5. Is this possible?

It's not clear to me what model_file's are so I am not sure how to convert DNA sequences to sentencepiece. I am using the python module. Right now I am getting `RuntimeError: Internal: src/sentencepiece_processor.cc(891) [model_proto->ParseFromArray(serialized.data(), serialized.size())] `

My goal is to use BigBird in Huggingface, which uses sentencepiece tokenization.

I appreciate your help. Thanks.

issue.title: create sentencepiece from own vocab file
issue.body:
I am very new to using sentencepiece.

I am trying to convert DNA sequences into sentencepiece. My file contains a list of sequences.
For example, two sequences would look like this:
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA
AAACGTGTGTGACCC
...
Using sentencepiece from pretrained English such as test/test_model.model, each DNA letter is considered a word. The ideal case would be to break down each sequence into a sequence of k-mers. For example,
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA consisting of three "words": ACTGC ACAGT CAGTA, if k=5. Is this possible?

It's not clear to me what model_file's are so I am not sure how to convert DNA sequences to sentencepiece. I am using the python module. Right now I am getting `RuntimeError: Internal: src/sentencepiece_processor.cc(891) [model_proto->ParseFromArray(serialized.data(), serialized.size())] `

My goal is to use BigBird in Huggingface, which uses sentencepiece tokenization.

I appreciate your help. Thanks.

comment.body:
We can limit the length of tokens with  ``--max_sentencepiece_length=5``. However, this setting extracts the pieces of length 1..5.

Creating the vocab is not supported. Currently, the model and vocab can only be generated with the trainer and the training data.
However, it is technically possible to manually edit the model file. Please check the previous threads.

comment.body:
As the error message indicates, the newly added token (piece) is already in the vocab. In addition, adding an empty piece is not allowed.

Manual updating of the model is out of the scope of support, so please update the model at your-own-risk-basis.

issue.title: Continuous Tokenizer Training
issue.body:
Hi there, 

Can we continue the training for a SentencePiece tokenizer? 
We got a English tokenizer with 10K vocab_size, and want to train the tokenizer on Chinese corpus to learn additional 5K tokens, to have a final tokenizer with 10K of English tokens at the beginning (start from index 0) and 5K of Chinese tokens follows (start from index 10,000). 
Can we do that?

comment.body:
Sentencepiece doesn't support continuous training, but you can try to merge two models (En/Zh models) trained independently.

The models file a serialized protobuf. We can merge the "pieces" fields in the proto.
https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/issues/121

pull_request.title: add CIFuzz GitHub action
pull_request.body:
Add [CIFuzz](https://google.github.io/oss-fuzz/getting-started/continuous-integration/) workflow action to have fuzzers build and run on each PR.

This is a service offered by OSS-Fuzz where sentencepiece already runs. CIFuzz can help detect regressions and catch fuzzing build issues early, and has a variety of features (see the URL above). In the current PR the fuzzers gets build on a pull request and will run for 300 seconds.

Signed-off-by: David Korczynski <david@adalogics.com>

issue.title: sentencepiece 0.1.97 re-released?
issue.body:
# Problem

I may be wrong, as far as I recalled, sentencepiece was released around June 6, 2022.

upstream monitoring system of debian, notified release of sentencepiece 0.1.97.
https://qa.debian.org/cgi-bin/watch?pkg=sentencepiece

Then that version of sentencepiece was packaged as 0.1.97-1.

After that, it seems that sentencepiece was released at Aug 7.
https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/releases/tag/v0.1.97

It causes mismatch of actual code base even though It says "0.1.97".
Could you release 0.1.98 in such a case?

Correct me, If I was wrong, @taku910

comment.body: We had several v0.1.97 releases, but only the last one is the official latest release, and others were labeled as "pre-release". (This release will be labeled as non-production ready).

issue.title: Recommended corpus size
issue.body:
My corpus has 60+ millions sentences.

When I train a SentencePiece tokenizer I get the following warning : 

> LOG(WARNING) Too many sentences are loaded! (60775390), which may slow down training.

I thought having as many training data as possible was a good thing. **But is there a specific training data size "soft limit" (i.e. adding more data over this limit wouldn't really change the output) ?**

comment.body:
We do not always need to train the model from larger data. I think sampling is sufficient.
Ssuwbword algorithm only uses the frequent 32-64k tokens.  The trend of frequent tokens does not change that much after sampling.

issue.title: Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" and "？" are not contained in the vocab
issue.body:
I used about 35m Chinese corpus to generate the Chinese vocab, here is my command：
`spm_train --input=test.zh --model_prefix=spm_zh --vocab_size=32000 --character_coverage=1`
but the spm_zh.vocab doesn't contain Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" ,  "？", "；", "：". Instead, the spm_zh.vocab contains English half-width punctuation such as "," ,  "?", ";", ":". 
In fact, most of the lines in my training corpus use Chinese full-width punctuation but not English half-width punctuation. And Chinese full-width punctuation is different with English half-width punctuation. For example,
`ch = '，'  `
`en = ','  `
`print('ch punc', ch.encode('utf-8')) `
`print('en punc', en.encode('utf-8')) `
`>>ch punc b'\xef\xbc\x8c'`
`>>en punc b','`
I change other Chinese corpus and change vocab_size, however, the problem is still not solved.
Should I set other hyperparameters？

issue.title: Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" and "？" are not contained in the vocab
issue.body:
I used about 35m Chinese corpus to generate the Chinese vocab, here is my command：
`spm_train --input=test.zh --model_prefix=spm_zh --vocab_size=32000 --character_coverage=1`
but the spm_zh.vocab doesn't contain Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" ,  "？", "；", "：". Instead, the spm_zh.vocab contains English half-width punctuation such as "," ,  "?", ";", ":". 
In fact, most of the lines in my training corpus use Chinese full-width punctuation but not English half-width punctuation. And Chinese full-width punctuation is different with English half-width punctuation. For example,
`ch = '，'  `
`en = ','  `
`print('ch punc', ch.encode('utf-8')) `
`print('en punc', en.encode('utf-8')) `
`>>ch punc b'\xef\xbc\x8c'`
`>>en punc b','`
I change other Chinese corpus and change vocab_size, however, the problem is still not solved.
Should I set other hyperparameters？

comment.body:
sentencepiece normalizes the input with Unicode NFKC by default, which includes the full/half width punctuations.
You can suppress the normalization with ``--normalization_rule_name=identity``.  We can also define application dependent
normalization rules.

https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/blob/master/doc/normalization.md

issue.title: different between command line tool and python with \n
issue.body:
I used two different ways to train a spm,but I find that the result are different.
```python
spm.SentencePieceTrainer.Train(
                                input = '/mnt/tiny.txt',
                                model_prefix='unigram_tiny', 
                                vocab_size=50000, 
                                model_type='unigram', 
                                character_coverage=0.9995, 
                                num_threads=120,
                                train_extremely_large_corpus=True,
                                control_symbols=['[PAD]', '<s>', '</s>', '[SPEAKER1]', '[SPEAKER2]', '[SEP]'],
                                pad_id=0,
                                unk_id=1,
                                bos_id=2,
                                eos_id=3,
                                pad_piece='[PAD]',
                                unk_piece='[UNK]',
                                bos_piece='<s>',
                                eos_piece='</s>',
                                byte_fallback=True,
                                add_dummy_prefix=False,
                                remove_extra_whitespaces=False,
                                user_defined_symbols=['\n', '\t', '\r', '\b'],
                                logstream=open('train-unigram.log', 'w'))```
and command line with :
```bash
spm_train --input=/mnt/tiny.txt --model_prefix ch_unigram_tiny --vocab_size 50000 --character_coverage 0.9995 --model_type unigram --control_symbols [PAD],\<s\>,\</s\>,[SPEAKER1],[SPEAKER2],[SEP] --user_defined_symbols='\n','\t','\r','\b' --pad_id 0 --unk_id 1 --bos_id 2 --eos_id 3 --pad_piece [PAD] --unk_piece [UNK] --bos_piece \<s\> --eos_piece \</s\> --unk_surface [UNK] --byte_fallback --train_extremely_large_corpus true --add_dummy_prefix false --remove_extra_whitespaces false --num_threads 120
```
when use unigram_tiny model,it can tokenize '\n' as a piece of '\n', but use ch_unigram_tiny to tokenize '\n', it return '▁' .
after check the 'vocab', I find the different:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16846988/195792264-bab17080-5847-4d05-b05d-522be0d86aae.png)

it looks like command line tool keep a wrong user defined symbol.
so which is right?and if I want to keep '\n', the python way is a good way to go?

comment.body: This is expected.  Unix shell usually handles the escape sequence as-is. i.e., the backslash is parsed as-is.

comment.body:
How did you build the binary?  

The cmake configuration will try to make shared library (DLL), but it doesn't work. Better to try a static link.
`
```cmake -A -B ./build -DSPM_BUILD_TEST=ON -DSPM_ENABLE_SHARED=OFF```

issue.title: create sentencepiece from own vocab file
issue.body:
I am very new to using sentencepiece.

I am trying to convert DNA sequences into sentencepiece. My file contains a list of sequences.
For example, two sequences would look like this:
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA
AAACGTGTGTGACCC
...
Using sentencepiece from pretrained English such as test/test_model.model, each DNA letter is considered a word. The ideal case would be to break down each sequence into a sequence of k-mers. For example,
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA consisting of three "words": ACTGC ACAGT CAGTA, if k=5. Is this possible?

It's not clear to me what model_file's are so I am not sure how to convert DNA sequences to sentencepiece. I am using the python module. Right now I am getting `RuntimeError: Internal: src/sentencepiece_processor.cc(891) [model_proto->ParseFromArray(serialized.data(), serialized.size())] `

My goal is to use BigBird in Huggingface, which uses sentencepiece tokenization.

I appreciate your help. Thanks.

ACTGCACAGTCAGTA consisting of three "words": ACTGC ACAGT CAGTA, if k=5. Is this possible?

It's not clear to me what model_file's are so I am not sure how to convert DNA sequences to sentencepiece. I am using the python module. Right now I am getting `RuntimeError: Internal: src/sentencepiece_processor.cc(891) [model_proto->ParseFromArray(serialized.data(), serialized.size())] `

My goal is to use BigBird in Huggingface, which uses sentencepiece tokenization.

I appreciate your help. Thanks.

comment.body:
We can limit the length of tokens with  ``--max_sentencepiece_length=5``. However, this setting extracts the pieces of length 1..5.

Creating the vocab is not supported. Currently, the model and vocab can only be generated with the trainer and the training data.
However, it is technically possible to manually edit the model file. Please check the previous threads.
